description: From Middle French fluxion, from Late Latin fluxiō, from Latin flūxus + -iō.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, mathematics) The derivative of a function.
(rare or archaic) The action of flowing.
examples: Perhaps he meant that towns are after all excrescences, grey fluxions, where men, hurrying to find one another, have lost themselves.

entries.meaning: (rare or archaic) A difference or variation.

verbs.description: fluxion (third-person singular simple present fluxions, present participle fluxioning, simple past and past participle fluxioned)

entries.meaning: (geology) To be distributed in a flowing pattern.
